situationalFactors.jsnStatus: NFL's leading receiver with 948 yards, on pace for 2,015-yard season (would shatter single-season record)
situationalFactors.matchup: Arizona ranked 29th in pass defense (261.4 YPG allowed)

keyFactors.title: Elite Volume Trend
keyFactors.description: JSN entered Week 10 as the NFL's leading receiver (948 yards). His 2,015-yard pace would break the single-season record. The volume and efficiency trends were historic.

keyFactors.title: Perfect Matchup
keyFactors.description: Arizona's 29th-ranked pass defense (261.4 YPG) represented ideal opponent. Cardinals struggled to contain top receivers all season.

keyFactors.title: Consistency Pattern
keyFactors.description: JSN recorded 75+ yards in every single game (8-of-8). This wasn't variance—it was systematic domination of target share and efficiency.

keyFactors.title: Sam Darnold Connection
keyFactors.description: Darnold averaged 178 passing yards with JSN as primary target. The chemistry and trust were evident in red zone and third-down situations.

riskFactors: Seattle's defense capable of scoring, reducing offensive plays
Cardinals' desperation could create unpredictable game script

gameFlow.description: JSN caught 43-yard TD on opening drive, instantly putting him at 43 yards. Seattle jumped ahead 7-0 and appeared headed for shootout.
DISASTER. DeMarcus Lawrence returned TWO fumbles for touchdowns (identical plays). Seattle led 38-7 at half WITHOUT needing offensive production. JSN added 50 yards but pace stalled.
With 38-7 halftime lead, Seattle ran 198 rushing yards in second half. Darnold attempted only 11 second-half passes (12 total for game). JSN finished 5-for-6, 93 yards, 1 TD.

gameResults.whenCleared: Never - finished 3.5 yards short despite 5-for-6 efficiency
gameResults.gamePace: Darnold threw only 12 total passes because defensive/special teams scores made offense ceremonial. JSN's 44.7% target share meant nothing when offense barely played.

whatWentWrong.title: Unpredictable Game Script Disaster
whatWentWrong.description: Seattle scored 38 first-half points with TWO identical DeMarcus Lawrence fumble return TDs. The defense dominated so thoroughly that the passing offense became irrelevant.

whatWentWrong.title: Second-Half Abandonment
whatWentWrong.description: Darnold attempted just 11 passes in the entire second half (12 total game). With 38-7 halftime lead, Seattle ran 198 second-half rushing yards, completely eliminating JSN's opportunities.

whatWentWrong.title: Microscopic Miss
whatWentWrong.description: JSN needed 3.5 more yards. ONE additional moderate catch would have cashed. He was 5-for-6 with 93 yards and a TD—elite efficiency wasted by circumstance, not performance.

whatWentWrong.title: Variance vs Skill
whatWentWrong.description: This was 95% variance, 5% error. No model predicts three defensive/special teams touchdowns creating a blowout before halftime. JSN's performance was excellent; the game environment killed the prop.

statisticalContext.targetShare: 6 targets on 12 attempts = 50% of passes (even higher than 44.7% average)
statisticalContext.comparableGames: In competitive games, JSN averages 112.3 yards. This blowout limited plays, not production.

alternateOutcomes.ifCompetitive: In normal game script with Darnold attempting 28-32 passes, JSN likely finishes with 120-140 yards given his efficiency (18.6 YPR)
alternateOutcomes.ifOneMoreCatch: ONE additional 15-yard catch (below his YPR average) would have cashed the over
alternateOutcomes.realityCheck: Seattle's defense scoring 14 points before offense played meaningful drives was the 1% outcome that killed an elite setup

closingLineValue.verdict: Excellent positive CLV - line moved significantly toward over as sharp money pounded JSN's historic pace and elite matchup. We got best available number early.

keyTakeaways: Even elite target share (44.7%) evaporates when game script eliminates offensive plays
JSN's 93 yards on 6 targets = elite efficiency, but 12 total pass attempts killed volume
Cannot predict three defensive/special teams TDs creating halftime blowout
This is textbook 'right process, wrong outcome' - everything aligned except unpredictable variance
Missing by 3.5 yards after 43-yard opening TD is brutal, but reflects variance not analytical error
Would make this bet 100 times in 100 similar situations - the edge was massive
verdict: Heartbreaking loss but analytically sound. When the NFL's leading receiver faces 29th-ranked pass defense with historic consistency, the prop offers massive edge. Defensive TDs creating early blowout was 1% variance that nullified elite setup.
